Calculating longnostics - statistics of interest for each individual

l_longnostic.Rd

Calculate statistical summaries for each individual, referred to as a longnostics, a portmanteau of longitudinal and cognostic - a term coined by Tukey which is itself a portmanteau of "cognitive" and "diagnostic". These longnostics all start with l_, and calculate a statistic for each individual in the data, who can be identified with some id, with the statistic being calculated for a specific variable. The current longnostics implemented are:

  • l_n_obs() Number of observations

  • l_min() Minimum

  • l_max() Maximum

  • l_mean() Mean

  • l_diff() Lagged difference (by default, the first order difference)

  • l_q1() First quartile

  • l_median() Median value

  • l_q3() Third quartile

  • l_sd() Standard deviation

  • l_slope() Slope and intercept (given some linear model formula)

l_mean(data, id, var)

l_sd(data, id, var)

l_max(data, id, var)

l_min(data, id, var)

l_median(data, id, var)

l_q1(data, id, var)

l_q3(data, id, var)

l_diff(data, id, var, lag = 1)

l_n_obs(data, id)

l_slope(data, id, formula)

Arguments

data

data.frame to explore
id

vector of ids to define which values belong to which individual
var

vector of values for individuals, needs to match the id vector
lag

the lag to use, default to 1 (used with l_diff)
formula

character, a formula representing the slope of interest (used in l_slope)

Value

dataframe with column id and l_statistic. For example, l_mean returns the columns id specified, and l_mean.

See also

The add_l_statistic set of functions which add a column for each id to the dataframe.

Examples

l_mean(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_mean
#>    <int>  <dbl>
#>  1    31   1.75
#>  2    36   2.33
#>  3    53   1.89
#>  4   122   2.17
#>  5   134   2.48
#>  6   145   1.76
#>  7   155   2.17
#>  8   173   1.93
#>  9   206   2.27
#> 10   207   2.11
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_sd(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id  l_sd
#>    <int> <dbl>
#>  1    31 0.277
#>  2    36 0.387
#>  3    53 0.562
#>  4   122 0.574
#>  5   134 0.321
#>  6   145 0.185
#>  7   155 0.362
#>  8   173 0.274
#>  9   206 0.228
#> 10   207 0.327
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_max(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_max
#>    <int> <dbl>
#>  1    31  2.13
#>  2    36  2.93
#>  3    53  3.24
#>  4   122  2.92
#>  5   134  2.93
#>  6   145  2.04
#>  7   155  2.64
#>  8   173  2.34
#>  9   206  2.48
#> 10   207  2.66
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_min(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_min
#>    <int> <dbl>
#>  1    31 1.43 
#>  2    36 1.80 
#>  3    53 1.54 
#>  4   122 0.763
#>  5   134 2.00 
#>  6   145 1.48 
#>  7   155 1.54 
#>  8   173 1.56 
#>  9   206 2.03 
#> 10   207 1.58 
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_median(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_median
#>    <int>    <dbl>
#>  1    31     1.73
#>  2    36     2.32
#>  3    53     1.71
#>  4   122     2.19
#>  5   134     2.36
#>  6   145     1.77
#>  7   155     2.22
#>  8   173     2.00
#>  9   206     2.30
#> 10   207     2.15
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_q1(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id  l_q1
#>    <int> <dbl>
#>  1    31  1.49
#>  2    36  2.05
#>  3    53  1.59
#>  4   122  2.12
#>  5   134  2.29
#>  6   145  1.60
#>  7   155  1.93
#>  8   173  1.76
#>  9   206  2.16
#> 10   207  1.90
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_diff(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_diff_1
#>    <int>    <dbl>
#>  1    31    0.377
#>  2    36    1.11 
#>  3    53    1.70 
#>  4   122    1.68 
#>  5   134    0.368
#>  6   145    0.289
#>  7   155    0.627
#>  8   173    0.319
#>  9   206    0.269
#> 10   207    0.399
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_diff(wages, id, lnw, lag = 2)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_diff_2
#>    <int>    <dbl>
#>  1    31    0.462
#>  2    36    0.775
#>  3    53    1.48 
#>  4   122    1.42 
#>  5   134    0.508
#>  6   145    0.440
#>  7   155    0.785
#>  8   173    0.417
#>  9   206    0.454
#> 10   207    0.482
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_q3(wages, id, lnw)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id  l_q3
#>    <int> <dbl>
#>  1    31  1.97
#>  2    36  2.54
#>  3    53  1.88
#>  4   122  2.42
#>  5   134  2.77
#>  6   145  1.88
#>  7   155  2.40
#>  8   173  2.02
#>  9   206  2.39
#> 10   207  2.24
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_n_obs(wages, id)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 2
#>       id l_n_obs
#>    <int>   <int>
#>  1    31       8
#>  2    36      10
#>  3    53       8
#>  4   122      10
#>  5   134      12
#>  6   145       9
#>  7   155      11
#>  8   173       6
#>  9   206       3
#> 10   207      11
#> # … with 878 more rows
l_slope(wages, id, lnw~exper)
#> # A tibble: 888 x 3
#>       id l_intercept l_slope_exper
#>    <int>       <dbl>         <dbl>
#>  1    31        1.41        0.101 
#>  2    36        2.04        0.0588
#>  3    53        2.29       -0.358 
#>  4   122        1.93        0.0374
#>  5   134        2.03        0.0831
#>  6   145        1.59        0.0469
#>  7   155        1.66        0.0867
#>  8   173        1.61        0.100 
#>  9   206        1.73        0.180 
#> 10   207        1.62        0.0884
#> # … with 878 more rows
